speaker: Rick Scott
vclaim: While Governor Rick Scott, Florida, "invested record funding in HIV/AIDS prevention."
date: stated on September 11, 2019 in a statement to The Guardian:
title: Rick Scott is misleading about "registered funding" for HIV prevention.
text: My investigation report from the Guardian found that when Mr. Rick Scott was Governor of Florida, he left millions of unexpended federal dollars to fight HIV. This prompted Scott to renew a familiar and misleading point of discussion on the financing of HIV/AIDS during his tenure as Governor. The Senate Bureau of Scott told The Guardian, a left-wing British newspaper, that Governor Scott "invested record funding in HIV/AIDS prevention." In 2016 we evaluated a similar statement from Scott about "financing registration" mostly wrong. Scott was referring to money that came almost entirely from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention while only a small fraction of the state budget came. Scott's spokespersons did not answer our questions this time. They argued vaguely against the Guardian's report by repeating the denial of registered funding. When a reporter asked the Bay News 9 Scott if there was any particular reason why the state did not use the money he said "no." There are two large federal funds designed to combat HIV: funds from the Centre for Disease Control for Prevention and funds from the Department of Resources and Health Services, known as Ryan White Funds, for treatment. When Scott talks about a preventive record, he refers to the federal funds of the Centre for Disease Control, which can be used in prevention programmes such as testing and condom distribution. The amount granted by the Centre for Disease Control during Scott State increased from about $19.4 million in 2011 to $34.8 million in 2016. (We asked the CDC and the Florida Ministry of Health for additional dollars for 2017 and 2018, but we did not hear a reply. We found that Florida added some of her money. The State provided an additional $1.4 million in 2015 for a public awareness campaign, a HIV hotline and four targeted awareness coordinators. When Scott signed the 2016-17 budget, he noted that the State ' s contribution to HIV/AIDS services had risen to $1.65 million - 002 per cent of the total State budget of $82 billion. As for the increase in federal funding for the Centre for Disease Control, this was not due to the increased efforts of the State. The funding formula takes into account the population, so Florida received more funding from the CDC than any other state except New York and California in 2015. The funds also take into account the incidence of patients and the numbers of patients. The Obama Administration aims to strengthen prevention efforts in communities where HIV is most concentrated. In other words, Florida has received an increase in federal funding because the state needs it. Check the facts (Kirk Cox) was mentioned on January 13, 2021 in a speech. Virginia ranked lowest third of the states in the management of the COVID-19 vaccine. On 20 January 2021, Scott refused an independent source of federal funding that could have helped patients living with HIV: expanding medical assistance under the Affordable Care Act. Increased coverage of medical aid in expanding states has led to increased coverage of people living with HIV throughout the country, as discovered by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Medical aid is the single largest source of coverage for people living with HIV. According to the Guardian investigation, Florida returned millions of dollars to The Guardian, which focused largely on what happened with the money that Florida received from Ryan White, which provided money for treatment. Between 2015 and 2017, Florida returned $54 million in unspent funds after the Ministry of Health failed to obtain permission from the legislature to spend them, as reported by the Guardian. Scott was a philosophy that rejected federal money in many circumstances. A spokesman for the Department of Resources and Health Services of the Polyte Fact Florida confirmed that the State had returned $54 million. It is common for states to return funds in compliance with federal rules. States must spend some drug reduction money before spending Ryan White's grant dollars. In 2016, 29 states returned money - anywhere from hundreds to millions of dollars. In 2014 and 2015, Florida returned the highest amounts from any state - $53 million. In the following year, Florida returned an additional $767,000. The Guardian reported that the number of new HIV infections had increased as the State had not contributed millions of dollars. Jin Kats, an HIV policy expert at the Kaiser Family Foundation, told Poletti Fuckett that investments in the right programs can drive infection rates down. "Honestly, there is certainly a link between investments and the epidemic," said Keats. "I cannot say in this case if what happened with this money has had an impact in either case." Our rule when Governor Scott, Florida, "invested record funding in HIV/AIDS prevention." Expenditure on HIV/AIDS prevention rose significantly during Scott's tenure as Governor, but mostly as a result of the rise in the value of CDC dollars. The state has begun much less. Those federal dollars went up because Florida, a large state with an increasing number of cases, needed money. The Scott Statement contains an element of right, but ignores critical facts that give a different impression. We mostly rate it wrong.
